thread.title: Towson football tries to make it two in a row vs. No. 23 Villanova
thread.title_full: Towson football tries to make it two in a row vs. No. 23 Villanova

author: Edward Lee
title: Towson football tries to make it two in a row vs. No. 23 Villanova
text:
var ssaUrl = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://' : 'http://') + 'pixel.sitescout.com/iap/0ea84626951144d2';new Image().src = ssaUrl;"/> College Football Towson football tries to make it two in a row vs. No. 23 Villanova Rob Ambrose Steve Ruark / Baltimore Sun 
Towson football coach Rob Ambrose speaks to an official during a game against St. Francis in Towson, Saturday, Sept. 12, 2015. 
Towson football coach Rob Ambrose speaks to an official during a game against St. Francis in Towson, Saturday, Sept. 12, 2015. (Steve Ruark / Baltimore Sun) Can Towson beat No. 23 Villanova to stay relevant in the CAA? 
VILLANOVA (3-3) @ TOWSON (3-3) 
Site: Johnny Unitas Stadium, Towson 
TV: Comcast SportsNet, Ch. 24 
Audio: 1300 AM, TowsonTigers.com 
Series: Villanova leads 7-4 
What’s at stake: The Tigers helped themselves enormously by outlasting Colonial Athletic Association foe Stony Brook, 21-14, a week ago. Not only did they collect their first win in the CAA this season and improve to 1-2 in the conference, but they also gave themselves an outside shot at the league championship and a potential spot in the NCAA Football Championship Subdivision playoffs. But to remain relevant, Towson — which is 2-1 at home this fall — must overcome the Wildcats and a little bit of history. Villanova, which is 2-1 in the conference and ranked No. 23 in the FCS, has won six of the past seven meetings between the CAA rivals, including the past three in Towson. The Wildcats broke a two-game losing streak by blanking Albany, 37-0, on Saturday. It marked their first shutout since a 45-0 win over Rhode Island on Nov. 9, 2013.
